summaries.body: Two cubs from the ice age from an extinct species of lion​ were recently uncovered in Siberia, perfectly frozen in the permafrost.

display_asset.credit: Josh Galemore/Savannah Morning News, via AP

summaries.body: The Department of Veterans Affairs is mired in a backlog of more than 425,000 appeals of disputed claims.
The writer-artist Frank Miller returns to Batman with "Dark Knight III: The Master Race," a comic book series whose first issue will be released on Wednesday.

display_asset.caption: This is Maartje, a cat from Gent, Belgium. She will not be intimidated.

summaries.body: After the police asked Belgians not to tweet details of antiterrorism raids over the weekend, people responded with photos of cats.

display_asset.caption: Victims being removed on Saturday from an area affected by the landslide in Kachin State, Myanmar.
display_asset.credit: Eleven Media Group, via Associated Press

summaries.body: Rescue workers in northern Myanmar continued the search for survivors after a deadly landslide buried an encampment of workers who scavenge for jade.

display_asset.caption: Sheldon Silver, right, is charged with honest services fraud, extortion and money laundering.
display_asset.credit: Sam Hodgson for The New York Times

summaries.body: How jurors are instructed to interpret evidence could sway deliberations in the trial of a New York State assemblyman, Sheldon Silver, which heads to closing arguments on Monday.
The New Orleans police have named a suspect in the shooting of a medical student, an incident that was captured on surveillance video.

display_asset.caption: Firefighters and police officers inspecting the south gate of the Yasukuni Shrine in Tokyo on Monday.
display_asset.credit: Shigeyuki Inakuma/Kyodo News, via Associated Press

summaries.body: A small explosion damaged a public toilet on the grounds of the contentious Yasukuni war shrine in Japan, drawing police bomb squad technicians and firefighters to the scene.

display_asset.caption: One Direction performed at the American Music Awards in Los Angeles on Sunday.

summaries.body: At the American Music Awards, One Direction won the top award and Celine Dion paid tribute to the victims of the Paris attacks with Edith Piaf's "Hymne à L'Amour."
The case of a Saudi artist who was sentenced to death on charges of apostasy follows a string of punishments that have fueled comparisons between Saudi Arabia and ISIS.

display_asset.caption: Nola in her enclosure last year at the San Diego Zoo Safari Park in Escondido, Calif.

summaries.body: Nola, one of only four known northern white rhinoceroses, was euthanized on Sunday at the San Diego Zoo Safari Park after her health deteriorated because of an infection.
The French police have released a photo of a third unidentified suicide attacker who blew himself up outside the Stade de France near Paris on Nov. 13.

display_asset.caption: Medics helped a man after a shooting in Bunny Friend Park in New Orleans on Sunday.
display_asset.credit: Michael Democker/NOLA.com The Times-Picayune, via Associated Press

summaries.body: At least 10 people were hospitalized on Sunday after a shooting at a New Orleans park where hundreds had gathered to film a music video.

display_asset.caption: Rescuers in Hpakant, Myanmar, on Sunday laid out the bodies of those killed in a landslide near a mine the day before.

summaries.body: A landslide near a jade mine in northern Myanmar has killed about 100 people, with many others still missing.

display_asset.caption: Kim Kardashian, left, was photographed by paparazzi as she left Los Angeles International Airport in February.

summaries.body: V.I.P.s will be able to bypass security and paparazzi at Los Angeles International Airport, which has approved a plan to turn a cargo area into a private entrance and lounge.

display_asset.caption: The skull of Winnipeg, the bear that inspired "Winnie-the-Pooh."

summaries.body: The skull of Winnipeg, the bear who inspired A.A. Milne's “Winnie-the-Pooh,” has gone on display for the first time at the Hunterian Museum in London.

display_asset.caption: Mayor David Bowers, longtime mayor of Roanoke, Va., apologized on Friday for his comments comparing Syrian refugee assistance and Japanese internment camps.
display_asset.credit: Heather Rousseau/The Roanoke Times, via Associated Press

summaries.body: David Bowers, the longtime mayor of Roanoke, Va., apologized for citing Japanese internment camps in his defense of limiting Syrian refugee assistance.
Singapore jailed six officials of an evangelical megachurch for a $35 million fraud that used church funds in a failed bid to turn the pastor's wife into a global pop star.

display_asset.caption: Washington College in Chestertown, Md., closed its campus earlier this week after a student who may have a rifle disappeared.
display_asset.credit: Matt Roth for The New York Times

summaries.body: The search for a missing Maryland college student who may be armed has taken a personal turn as people reach out to him in social media posts addressed to “Jacob.”

display_asset.caption: An ancient amulet depicting the Egyptian goddess Isis.

summaries.body: For people, companies and Egyptian deities also named Isis, the association with the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria has created problems, including vandalism.

display_asset.credit: Lucara Diamond Corp / European Pressphoto Agency

summaries.body: A 1,111-carat diamond, a bit smaller than a tennis ball, was found in a mine in Botswana. It's the second largest gem-quality diamond ever discovered.
A Thai waitress in California has gotten an outpouring of tips after an image of one customer's receipt, saying that tips are “for U.S. citizens only," was posted online.

display_asset.caption: Sheldon Harnick is a titan of musical theater, best known for writing the words to “Fiddler on the Roof.” Now he’s 91, and he’s not slowing down.
display_asset.title: A Legendary Lyricist

summaries.body: Sheldon Harnick is a titan of musical theater, best known for writing the words to “Fiddler on the Roof.” Now he’s 91, and he’s not slowing down.

display_asset.caption: The image of a professor at the law school defaced with black tape. The Harvard police were investigating the taping of images on Thursday morning as a hate crime.

summaries.body: Black slashes of tape appeared across the portraits of some African-American law professors at Harvard, which is investigating the incident as a hate crime.
New York City has declared so-called hoverboards to be illegal, since they cannot be registered as vehicles with the state. Users could be fined up to $200.
Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain plans to join the club of world leaders with an official aircraft.
Facebook is making it a little less awkward to manage a breakup online. It is testing tools to help users review past posts and to adjust what they (and their exes) can see.

display_asset.caption: Jonathan Flothow, a steam system specialist, at Kips Bay Court, where about 95 percent of the radiators in one building have been retrofitted.
display_asset.credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

summaries.body: Simple, cheap fixes could make the clanging pipes and radiators in New York buildings more efficient -- and cut carbon emissions -- a new study says.

display_asset.caption: The New York Times film critics review “Carol,” “The Hunger Games: Mockingjay Part 2” and “Legend.”
display_asset.credit: Produced by By AINARA TIEFENTHÄLER and ROBIN LINDSAY

sectionFrontImages.credit: Wilson Webb/The Weinstein Company, via Associated Press

display_asset.title: This Week’s Movies | Nov. 20, 2015

summaries.body: The New York Times film critics review this week's movies, including, “Carol,” “The Hunger Games: Mockingjay Part 2” and “Legend.”
A transgender woman in England was found dead last week in a men's prison. Vicky Thompson had requested a transfer to a women's facility, her friends said.
